'''Lester Greenspan Telser''' (born January 3, 1931 in [[Chicago]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[economist]] and [[Professor Emeritus]] in Economics at the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name="dir"/>

==Education and career==
He is a native of the [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]] neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago and a graduate of the Chicago Public Schools (Charles Kozminski elementary school and Hyde Park High School (now [[Hyde Park Academy High School]])) and [[Roosevelt University]], where he studied under [[Abba Lerner]]. He received his [[Ph.D.]] from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1956. He taught briefly at [[Iowa State University]] and was conscripted into the [[United States Army]] in which he served from 1956-1958. He has been a member of the University of Chicago faculty since 1958 (now emeritus).<ref name="dir">[http://economics.uchicago.edu/faculty.shtml Faculty listing], University of Chicago Economics Department, retrieved 2010-01-07.</ref> He was a visitor at the [[Cowles Foundation]] (which had formerly been at the University of Chicago) at [[Yale University]] in 1964-1965 and at the Center for Operations Research in Econometrics (CORE) at the Catholic University of Louvain ([[Universit√© catholique de Louvain]]) in Louvain ([[Leuven]], [[Belgium]]) in 1969-1970.

==Contributions==
His works include research on the [[Core (economics)|theory of the core]], [[Federal Reserve]] policy, and [[integer programming]].<ref name="dir"/> Unusually for the [[Chicago school of economics]], he also wrote about [[game theory]] as early as 1972.<ref>[http://homepage.newschool.edu/het/schools/chicago.htm The Chicago School], History of Economic Thought web site, [[The New School]], retrieved 2010-01-07.</ref>

A brief, personal history by Lester Telser of the [[University of Chicago]] Economics Department including the importance of the [[Cowles Foundation]] is available as part of a symposium on "Living the Legacy: Chicago Economics through the Years."<ref>Living the Legacy: Chicago Economics through the Years.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pPzxHNHcg5Y], retrieved 2015-10-28.</ref>

==Awards and honors==
He has been a [[Fellow]] of the [[Econometric Society]]
and of the [[American Statistical Association]] since 1968.<ref>[http://www.econometricsociety.org/fellows.asp Fellows of the Econometric Society as of July 2009], retrieved 2010-01-07.</ref><ref>[http://www.amstat.org/careers/fellowslist.cfm ASA Fellows], retrieved 2010-01-07.</ref>

==Books==
*''Functional Analysis in Mathematical Economics: Optimization Over Infinite Horizons'' (with Robert L. Graves, 1972).<ref>University of Chicago Press, 1972, ISBN 978-0-226-79190-6.</ref>
*''Competition, Collusion, and Game Theory'' (1972).<ref>Macmillan, 1972, ISBN 978-0-333-13644-7; Aldine treatises in modern economics, 1972, ISBN 978-0-202-06043-9; Transaction, 2007, ISBN 978-0-202-30925-5.</ref>
*''Economic Theory and the Core'' (1978).<ref>University of Chicago Press, 1987, ISBN 978-0-226-79191-3. University of Chicago Press, 1988, ISBN 978-0-226-79193-7.</ref>
*''A Theory of Efficient Cooperation and Competition'' (1987).<ref>Cambridge University Press, 1987, ISBN 978-0-521-30619-5. Cambridge University Press, 2005, ISBN 978-0-521-02220-0.</ref>
*''Theories of Competition'' (1988).<ref>North-Holland, 1988, ISBN 978-0-444-01248-7.</ref>
*''Joint Ventures of Labor and Capital'' (1997).<ref>University of Michigan Press, 1997, ISBN 978-0-472-10866-4.</ref>
*''Classic Futures: Lessons from the Past for the Electronic Age''.<ref>Risk, 2000, ISBN 978-1-899332-92-2.</ref>
*''The Core Theory in Economics: Problems and Solutions'' (2007).<ref>Routledge, 2007, ISBN 978-0-415-70144-0; Taylor and Francis, 2009, ISBN 978-0-415-49365-9.</ref>
